snippet: A horn was still blown, three blasts beinggiven at nine o'clock at the Market Cross and three immediatelyafterwards at the Mayor's door by the official horn-blower, during whichperformances the seventh bell in the cathedral was tolled.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: A dying man when he was put in the Tolbooth, he yet had toundergo many exhausting examinations and a farcical trial, with "BluidyMackenzie" for chief inquisitor, and on Christmas Eve, 1684, hegallantly and cheerfully met a martyr's death at the Market Cross ofEdinburgh.

title: Stories of the Border Marches

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: I saw and ascended the ancient Market Cross of Preston, — once the centre  of the village, now the chief object visible  in a market garden, — and I viewed the forlorn fragments that yet remain of Preston Castle, not far away.

title: Four years in the Old world;
author: Palmer, Phoebe
snippet: At the point from which these four streets diverge stands an ancient stone monument, doubtless centuries old, called the Market Cross.

title: Four years in the Old world;
author: Palmer, Phoebe
snippet: The " White Cross," the " Market Cross," the " Weeping CrosS," and the far-famed " Banbury Cross " of nursery notoriety, were all here or in the region round about.

title: The footpath and highway:

snippet: memory of Sir Walter Scott, eighty feet high; and pedestrian statues to Sir John Moore, and Watt, the improver of the steam- engine ; while in front of the Exchange is a bronze equestrian image of Wellington, and in the Irongate, at the Market Cross, one of William of Orange.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: They then burned it publicly at the Market Cross, where after four hundred horns and twenty brass trumpets had proclaimed defiance, they stigmatized " the king, the lord Crichton, Sir Alexander  Livingstone, Sir Patrick Gray, and all who adhered to them, as false and perjured traitors ! "

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: "By the God of my kin, our task of vengeance is beginning !'* cried Earl James, rising in his stirrups, and brandishing his sword ; " a rope, a rope ! A Douglas ! a Douglas ! Ho, Pompherston, Glendoning, Cairnglas, — let us hang this king's minion at the Market Cross ! Gather a band — beset the house, and watch every avenue.

title: Gray Days and Gold ... New edition, revised, with illustrations
author: Winter, William
snippet: where the mangled body of the heroic Argyle waslaid, in secret sanctuary, for several nights after thatscene of piteous sacrifice at the old Market Cross ; andwhen you walk in the solemn enclosure of the Grayfriars church, — so fitly styled, by Sir Walter, TheWestminster Abbey of Scotland, — your glance willfall upon a sunken pillar, low down upon the northernslope of that haunted, lamentable ground, which bearsthe letters " I. M.," and which marks the grave of thebaleful Morton, whom the Maiden decapitated, for hisshare in the murder of Rizzio.

title: His Dearest Wish. A novel

snippet: Edinburgh, was no stranger to the laird'sintense desire to suffer on the gibbet, beganto cry out in a loud voice a broadside, whichsome wag had caused to be printed soonafter the demolition of the Market Cross.

title: His Dearest Wish. A novel
author: Ware, Mary Clementina Hibbert.
snippet: On the breezy day of October we havementioned, near the spot where had stoodthe Market Cross, and in front of theLucken Booths, a row of houses and shopsstanding under the shade of the old church,there was gathered together an unusuallylarge concourse of people, all engaged inearnest and animated conversation.

title: His Dearest Wish. A novel
author: Ware, Mary Clementina Hibbert.
snippet: Here, at the Market Cross, from timeimmemorial, the citizens were wont to meet,between the hours of twelve and one, totransact business ; but, in fact, the placewas a sort of parade, for people met therealso to hear the news of the day.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: Now I would gang to hear MaisterKnox preach in the St. Giles, anon to the Grass Market to seesome poor wretch justified, or to the Market Cross to listen tosome proclamation by the queen or the lords of the Congregatio—neither, it would seem, being so happy as when fightingone another with sword or pen—or, as I had been that day, tothe Crags.
